text.*:
"Work-shy" redirects here. For the British band, see Workshy. For the German word meaning "work-shy", see Arbeitsscheu.
This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (April 2011) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

Work aversion (or aversion to work) is the state of avoiding or not wanting to work or be employed, or the extreme preference of leisure as opposed to work.see Leighton Davies[citation needed] It can be attributed to laziness, boredom or burnout.[1] Work aversion is not a recognized psychological disorder in the DSM-IV.[citation needed]

Contents

  • 1 Causes
  • 2 Treatment
  • 3 See also
  • 4 References
  • 5 Further reading
  • 6 External links

Causes[edit]

This section needs expansion. You can help by adding to it. (November 2017)

Work aversion usually occurs in persons who have previously been employed, and can have a variety of causes. These include:

  • Boredom with work:[1] Holding a boring job early in life can lead to the impression later that all work is boring.[2]

Treatment[edit]

This section needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (November 2017) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

The mental health community does not recognize work aversion as an illness or disease and therefore no medically recognized treatments exist. Those attempting to treat work aversion as an illness may use psychotherapy, counseling, medication, or some more unusual forms of treatment.

In the case where the person has not worked for a while due to a workplace injury, work-hardening can be used to build strength. The person works for a brief period of time in the first week, such as two hours per day and increases the amount of work each week until full-time hours are reached.[3]

  • Disability fraud
  • Drapetomania
  • Ergophobia
  • Refusal of work
  • Work ethic
  • Work-leisure dichotomy

References[edit]

  1. ^ a b Boyes, Roger (2007-09-15). "Forget burnout, boreout is the new office disease". The Times. London. 
  2. ^ Fast Food Nation: The Dark Side of the All-American Meal - Eric Schlosser - Google Books. Books.google.com. Retrieved 2013-07-04. 
  3. ^ "The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search". news.google.com. 

Further reading[edit]

  • The Abolition of Work, a 1985 essay by Bob Black.
  • The Abolition of Work and Other Myths, Neala Schleuning, (Summer, 1995), a response to Black's essay
